hotels.name: Hilton Warsaw Hotel and Convention Centre

attractions.title: Zamek Królewski
attractions.paragraph: The castle was originally built in the 14th century, but was largely destroyed during World War II. It was meticulously reconstructed in the decades that followed, using original plans, photographs, and documents, and was finally reopened to the public in 1984. It is one of Warsaw's most popular tourist destinations, drawing visitors from all over the world to explore its ornate interiors, stunning architecture, and fascinating history and is home to a variety of museums and exhibits, including the Royal Apartments and the Great Assembly Hall, where the country's parliament once convened.

attractions.title: Ogród Saski
attractions.paragraph: Ogród Saski, or the Saxon Garden, is a beautiful and historic public park located in the heart of Warsaw, Poland. This idyllic green space provides a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city, and is a popular destination for both tourists and locals alike. Ogród Saski features winding paths, lush gardens, and a variety of historic monuments and sculptures, making it a favorite spot for picnics, strolls, and relaxation. One of the most impressive features of the park is the Palace on the Water, a beautifully restored 18th-century palace that now houses a museum dedicated to the history and culture of Poland.

attractions.title: Puszcza Kampinowska
attractions.paragraph: Puszcza Kampinowska is a beautiful and expansive forest located just outside of Warsaw, Poland. This pristine wilderness area is a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts and nature lovers, and offers a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life. The forest covers over 300 square kilometers and features a wide variety of landscapes, including dense forests, winding rivers, and rolling hills. One of the most popular activities in Puszcza Kampinowska is hiking, with a variety of trails available for visitors of all skill levels.

attractions.title: Łazienki Królewskie
attractions.paragraph: This magnificent park, located in the heart of the city, is a sprawling complex of gardens, palaces, and historic monuments, and offers visitors a unique glimpse into the city's rich cultural and architectural heritage. The park was established in the 18th century as a summer residence for King Stanisław August Poniatowski, and features a variety of stunning architectural features, including the iconic Palace on the Water, which appears to float on a tranquil lake. In addition to the palace, the park features a variety of other historic buildings, including the Old Orangery, the White House, and the Myślewicki Palace.

attractions.title: Stare Miasto (Old Town)
attractions.paragraph: As you stroll through Stare Miasto, you'll be transported back in time to the medieval era, when the district was first established. The area is home to many well-preserved buildings and structures, including the Royal Castle, the Barbican, and the St. John's Cathedral. These landmarks provide an insight into the rich history and culture of Poland.\n\nIn addition to its historical sites, Stare Miasto is also known for its bustling cafes, restaurants, and shops. The area is a hub for local artists and artisans, and you can find a wide variety of traditional Polish crafts and souvenirs.

attractions.title: Fryderyk Chopin Museum
attractions.paragraph: The Fryderyk Chopin Museum in Warsaw, Poland is a must-visit destination for music lovers and history buffs alike. This modern museum is dedicated to the life and legacy of Fryderyk Chopin, one of the greatest composers in the history of classical music.\n\nLocated in the heart of Warsaw's historic district, the Fryderyk Chopin Museum is housed in a beautifully restored 17th-century palace. The museum is home to an extensive collection of Chopin's personal belongings, including manuscripts, letters, and instruments, as well as interactive exhibits that allow visitors to explore his life and music in depth.

speakers.name: Maya Shavin
speakers.bio: Maya is Senior Software Engineer in Microsoft, working extensively with JavaScript and frontend frameworks and based in Israel. She founded and is currently the organizer of the VueJS Israel Meetup Community, helping to create a strong playground for Vue.js lovers and like-minded developers. Maya is also a published author, international speaker and an open-source library maintainer of frontend and web projects. As a core maintainer of StorefrontUI framework for e-commerce, she focuses on delivering performant components and best practices to the community while believing a strong Vanilla JavaScript knowledge is necessary for being a good web developer. She can be reached at her blog (https://mayashavin.com), on Twitter @mayashavin, or via email.
speakers.talkTitle: The art of visualization and composition in building component systems.
speakers.talkDescription: Let's face it, understanding a long page of specs is not always a trivial task to do. Same as building a complex component system. Let's explore how we can combine visualization and composition API to create our reusable and visual-able logic system for your components, ready to use in Vue application.

speakers.name: Tejas Kumar
speakers.bio: Tejas is an international Keynote speaker and software engineer who shares best practices with engineers.
speakers.talkDescription: 2022 saw the rise of new paradigms, from Qwik to SolidJS to SvelteKit 1.0. This talk explores the current and predicted state of frontend frameworks and enables engineers to be in the loop and make the best choice for their teams.

speakers.name: Roy Derks
speakers.bio: Roy is an entrepreneur, speaker and author from The Netherlands and, in his own words, 'wants to make the world a better place through tech'. He has been giving talks and training to developers worldwide on technologies like GraphQL, React and TypeScript. Most recently he wrote the books Fullstack GraphQL and React Projects.
speakers.talkDescription: Let's face it, there are many advantages to using GraphQL compared to REST APIs. But if you strip it down to the network protocol, it's using HTTP just as REST. We developers need to write a lot of imperative code to retrieve data to display in our applications and handle state. With GraphQL you can, when using the correct libraries, decrease the amount of code needed around data fetching and state-management. Next to increased flexibility, better performance and most of all an improved developer experience. In this talk I show GraphQL's magic and how (in the end) it's just HTTP.
speakers.Technologies: GraphQL, JavaScript, Data fetching, state management

speakers.name: Keren Kenzi
speakers.bio: Keren is a senior software engineer with over a decade of experience in the industry. She holds an M.Sc. in Computer Science and is passionate about React and learning new technologies. Keren volunteers as a program manager at Baot, a community that supports women in R&D in their professional growth. She instructs and inspires developers to write blogs in her tech blogging workshops. Keren has experience as a dev community leader and a co-organizer of meetups and events. And in her not-so-spare time, she studies psychology. Her hobbies include drawing, photography, and singing.
speakers.talkDescription: There is a saying that the best way to learn something is to teach it to someone else. When we write a tech blog, we share our knowledge with others and deepen our understanding of the subject. We also improve other skills along the way and build our professional brand and signature.In this talk, we will discuss the benefits of writing a blog and try to remove all the barriers that have stopped us so far from writing a blog.

speakers.name: Vadym Tarasich
speakers.bio: A Frontend developer with a great passion for the no-bullshit approach. Loves challenges and solving tricky cases. Big fan of improving things and throwing dead code out
speakers.talkTitle: How do we build games? Connecting past, present and future.
speakers.talkDescription: How did we create our game framework with React + Redux and build dozens of games? How we have solved problems of introducing new tech to large codebases and connecting Redux and Mobx.

speakers.name: Yonatan Kra
speakers.bio: Yonatan has been involved in some awesome projects in the academy and the industry - from C/C++ through Matlab to PHP and JavaScript. Former CTO at Webiks and Software Architect at WalkMe. Currently he is a software architect at Vonage and an egghead instructor.
speakers.talkTitle: Classic design patterns for the modern JS developer
speakers.talkDescription: In this session we will learn how and why classic software design patterns are relevant for the modern frontend developer - and how to leverage then for everyday challenges.All with live coding examples based on real world use-cases

schedule.author: Tejas Kumar
schedule.title: The modern frontend ecosystem (keynote)
schedule.description: 2022 saw the rise of new paradigms, from Qwik to SolidJS to SvelteKit 1.0. This talk explores the current and predicted state of frontend frameworks and enables engineers to be in the loop and make the best choice for their teams.

schedule.author: Maya Shavin
schedule.title: Visualize your State Management with XState
schedule.description: Learn a new concept to start your developing process - advanced XState for complex State Management in modern web applications, and start building complex architecture visually!

schedule.author: Keren Kenzi
schedule.title: Get your forms hooked with react-hook-form
schedule.description: As Front-end developers, we all know that forms can get really messy, but what if I told you that there is a library out there that can make your life much easier. In this talk, I'll introduce react-hook-form, a library that started to gain more and more popularity. It is super light, intuitive, performant, and flexible with easy-to-use validation. We'll cover its basics through a live code example and learn about its benefits. In addition, I will share with you my thoughts about what to look for when choosing a library to use.

schedule.author: Roy Derks
schedule.title: GraphQL is just HTTP
schedule.description: Let's face it, there are many advantages to using GraphQL compared to REST APIs. But if you strip it down to the network protocol, it's using HTTP just as REST. We developers need to write a lot of imperative code to retrieve data to display in our applications and handle state. With GraphQL you can, when using the correct libraries, decrease the amount of code needed around data fetching and state-management. Next to increased flexibility, better performance and most of all an improved developer experience. In this talk I show GraphQL's magic and how (in the end) it's just HTTP.

schedule.author: Yonatan Kra
schedule.title: Test Drive Your Code
schedule.description: What can software developers learn from doctors, scientists and martial artists? During my years as a developer I’ve written lots of software. Ranging from data related like image processing, sound analysis and synthesis, and data analysis to working on fullstack web applications. I’ve picked up some skills in various fields like performance, design patterns and devops. In this talk I’m going to share with you the one thing that makes me a better developer than my younger self - automated tests. You will learn how tests can improve your code, how to write better tests, how to use code coverage and how it is all related to medicine, housekeeping work and martial arts.

schedule.author: Vadym Tarasich
schedule.title: How do we build games? Connecting past, present and future
schedule.description: How did we create our game framework with React + Redux and build dozens of games? How we have solved problems of introducing new tech to large codebases and connecting Redux and Mobx.

schedule.author: Marek Kirejczyk
schedule.title: The magic of continuous delivery
schedule.description: Discover effective techniques that teams can utilize to enhance their performance, which are frequently neglected amidst the hustle and bustle of scrum ceremonies and docker containers.

venue.desc: BEC Poland (www.bec.dk/poland/) is the full-service IT house providing financial tech solutions for major Danish banks. With branches in Denmark and Poland, we enable their customers to invest online, take out loans, and transfer money. In other words, we do everything it takes to run a bank.
venue.about: The event will take place at Emilii Plater 53 - 23rd floor of BEC Poland our Diamond sponsor! BEC is the full-service IT house providing financial tech solutions for major Danish banks. With branches in Denmark and Poland, we enable their customers to invest online, take out loans, and transfer money. In other words, we do everything it takes to run a bank.

info.desc: Welcome to ConfrontJS, the premier conference for medium level and advanced front-end developers. Our conference is designed to bring together industry leaders, developers, and enthusiasts who are eager to share their knowledge and experience in the latest front-end technologies and trends.
info.heroDesc: This year we are hosting great guests with topics spanning very wide area of technical (and not only) knowledge...
info.whyDesc: Big know-how, small and big tech in a big city. Meet ConfrontJS
